node.title: ‘American Underdog’ Review: A Football Fairy Tale
node.alt: Anna Paquin and Zachary Levi in “American Underdog.”
node.description: Zachary Levi plays the N.F.L. star Kurt Warner in this biopic. It’s a wan parable about love and hard work.
node.content: ["The biopic \u201cAmerican Underdog\u201d centers on the quarterback Kurt Warner, a football player from Iowa who had an unconventional rise to becoming a National Football League champion. Warner\u2019s story is inspirational but intricate, and this wan film struggles to balance simple storytelling with the complexities of the sport.", "Unlike many football stars, Warner (Zachary Levi) wasn\u2019t drafted into the N.F.L. after graduating from college. For years following his graduation from the University of Northern Iowa in 1993, Warner worked at a grocery store, building highlight reels to send to sports agents on his time off. The film begins in this fallow period, dramatizing how Warner met Brenda (Anna Paquin), the woman who would become his wife. The couple shared common faiths in Christianity and each other. With Brenda by his side, Warner was eventually given a place on an arena football team. The opportunity enabled Warner to prove himself at a professional level, if not yet on an N.F.L. scale \u2014 that would come afterward, in 1997, with an offer from the St. Louis Rams (now the Los Angeles Rams). The rest, to football fans, is history.", "Romance was an important part of Warner\u2019s story, and the performances from Levi and Paquin are convincing \u2014 a feat, given their characters\u2019 inexplicably helmet-headed hairstyles. But the film has minimal insight into how Warner navigated the institution of professional football. The movie\u2019s directors, the brothers Jon and Andrew Erwin (\u201cWoodlawn,\u201d \u201cI Still Believe\u201d), glaze over the details that depict how teams seek talent. Warner\u2019s triumphs seem to rest more on his noble character than on gameplay specifics \u2014 a dubious notion given the N.F.L.\u2019s competitive standards.", "The Erwins\u2019 film presents a parable of how love and hard work can lead a hero down a prosperous, predetermined path. It\u2019s a pleasant narrative, but it feels like the picture-book version of a more complicated story."]
